page.title: 09THORNTON HOUGH
page.content: Most of the present day buildings were built in a similar style about 100 years ago by{Joseph Hirst}and William Lever, the first{Viscount Leverhulme.} {Hirst}was a{wealthy}man who lived in the White House next to the present Primary School. He built a church, vicarage and school. In 1891 he {sold }Thornton Manor to William Lever. There are{two churches}in Thornton Hough. The parish church of{All {Saints}has{five clock faces}on its tower because{Joseph Hirst}was unable to see the church clock from his house so he had built a smaller clock above the east clock.{St. George's,}now a United Reformed Church, was built as a {replica}of a Norman Church both inside and out. Leverhulme replaced an old smithy with a new smithy complete with a chestnut tree in front. It is still in use today.
